Other: Does it ever leak?
Zaltys:
Have to admit that it does. The `----` that is, not the contents.
If the default bias is on, whenever the AI tries to output `***` and fails, it might go for `----` instead as it's the second most common separator. So if you use `----` entries, might be worth banning it. No side-effects from doing that.

Other: I tried adding `[ Style: verbose, evocative, purple prose, descriptive ]` but it's not as descriptive as I want it to be. I use Euterpe btw.
Zaltys:
That'd be why. `Style:` wasn't yet included in Euterpe, so no wonder it doesn't work there.
As for more descriptive prose: most importantly, use third person. And secondly, switch to a preset that allows a wider variety of output, such as Ouroboros, as the default preset defaults to plain text due to how shallow the token pool is. Then — if you can't write descriptive prose yourself — just keep retrying until you get something descriptive, and keep generating from there. It'll catch on soon enough.

Other: Outputs are not good for me, mostly unrelated to the prompt. And often abotu an old man for some reason
Zaltys:
Tried a different summary. ```Summary: The Keepers are a secret sect that has been maintaining an ancient library for thousand years or more — nobody knows for how long. It is said to contain all the knowledge of the world.
***
What is real? Is the "real" world more than just the physical one we live in, with our senses and our brains? What if there was a place where something more substantial exists beyond the borders of our space and time?
The theory goes like this: Imagine two parallel lines, so far away from each other they can't be seen by the naked eye. Both lines are moving at the same speed in the exact same direction. One line represents the physical world, filled with objects such as stars, planets, trees, rocks, water, air, people, and so on. The second line represents the universe of ideas — every book ever written, every song ever sung, every thought that's ever occurred to anyone who ever lived.
Now imagine those two lines are approaching each other until they eventually meet. Every single idea in this universe will cross over into the physical realm, changing it in ways we don't even begin to understand. This is the moment of convergence when the physical and the metaphysical come face to face. At that very moment, the lines meet, creating one single line instead of two. It would look like a huge wave, rippling out towards infinity.
That moment is called the Great Convergence, and it is coming to pass now. For thousands of years, the Keepers have been preparing for it.
***
Once upon a time, there was no Librarian. There was no Library. Once upon a time, there were no books. There were no people. The earth had not yet formed. The sun had not yet begun its journey through the heavens. Life had not yet begun to crawl from the primeval seas.
Once upon a time, there was only darkness.
This is what you were told, what was always taught. I say once upon a time because such stories of the ancient past cannot be proven, and even if they could be, their validity is unimportant. What matters is what happened after that first moment, when light was born out of darkness.
But that too is only myth, for the truth of things never came down to us in any way other than metaphorical. A story is what it is. The first idea is the seed from which a multitude grew. Ideas are more important than facts.```  Dunno where this is going, but that's typical for `Magic Library`. <:shrug:332268181517238272>

Other: Can you elaborate on why?
Zaltys:
And rn/m, i/l/I in some fonts, etc. Add to this that some pages are often scanned a bit askew, making it even harder for the software to understand...
I've done OCR scans for the dataset, but they're generally so time-consuming that I try to avoid them. Unless it's something that we really need. Could add twenty other books in the same time from epubs, etc.

Other: Would you ever consider doing a video of you showing off how to clean and format a dataset?
Zaltys:
I doubt I could find time for it. Most of the important things are in the wiki - https://naidb.miraheze.org/wiki/Datasetting_for_AI_Modules
But an automated tool for actually fixing those would be great.

Other: I can't wait for module v2 to pick up on my every mistake in my training data and shove it back into my face.
Zaltys: Could definitely use some kind of web-based error checker for module data. (I mostly use Notepad++ scripts, not exactly useful for general use.)

Other: would you say attributes put a certain emphasis on what you input vs regular prose, where everything is considered pretty equally unless you configure biases?
Zaltys: Attributes is built so that it should generate decent prose regardless of what's in the fields. Be it lists or prose.

Other: How differently would you say attribute prose and regular prose are considered by the AI? Like, say you'd have prose unformatted vs the same prose formatted in attributes.
Zaltys: Depends a lot on the field. Some of them work better with prose than others. `Attributes:` itself is mainly lists, whereas something like `Summary:` is always prose.

Other: he says *badly phrased* prose is worse than attributes. I said earlier, *if phrased well*, if you remember.
Zaltys: Yep. I'd say that Attributes works decently and definitely beats _bad_ prose, but there's certainly room for improvement. I'll keep working on it...

Other: But it might also be a placebo effect, I don't know.
Zaltys: Nah. ATTG only appears after <|endoftext|>, so it's heavily associated with a new story. Wouldn't want that in _middle_ of one. Worse than sticking `⁂` in there.

Other:
So.... Basically.... Typical Sampling is good at making tokens highly likely if they are in a lot of Phrases or stories in the fine-tune or training set. 
If it's a common token in the data, or among many stories, then with typical it's highly likely to be chosen. 
Rare things are less likely to be chosen. 
If it's more diverse across the data or the Ai has "seen" it more often, then the Ai is more biased to pick it?
Zaltys: Yes.

Other: Here's the way it works. The AI sees there's a lot of brackets in the text it is being sent. "Aha!" it thinks to itself, "I must generate a lot of brackets myself to follow the pattern!" and it tries to do so. But oh no, all generations that contain the brackets are auto-blocked (since it's a banned token). When the most likely generation gets rejected, the AI resorts to the second most likely generation, and so on, until it finds an output that doesn't get blocked. This means that a lot of the AI's output becomes the AI's second, third, or tenth choice, and that means it's not as good.
Zaltys:
Usually not a concern. You can test it by disabling the bracket ban. []s don't leak if you switch to normal text in context.
In some cases v4 is taught by using datablocks. So those can work nicely in LB too.
